Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about Tom Sawyer's character inspiration and Mark Twain's childhood memories from Hannibal, Missouri. Here's what the search revealed:

## Character Inspiration from Childhood Memories

Twain based The Adventures of Tom Sawyer largely on his personal memories of growing up in Hannibal in the 1840s.(no content)In 1890, Twain reported to his friend Brander Matthews that the writing of Tom Sawyer had been accompanied for him by a series of vivid memories from his youth in rural Missouri.

## Hannibal, Missouri as Setting

It is set in the 1830s-1840s in the town of St. Petersburg, which is based on Hannibal, Missouri, where Twain lived as a boy.(no content)Hannibal, Missouri made Mark Twain, and, in turn, Twain made Hannibal famous. Few American authors are as closely intertwined — and influenced — by their hometowns as Twain. The childhood years spent in this Missouri town gave birth to some of the most famous characters in American literature, an emotional and memory-filled well that Twain would return to again and again.

## Real-Life Inspirations for Tom Sawyer

In the preface, Twain says that "Huck Finn is drawn from life" (primarily, according to the author, from a childhood friend named Tom Blankenship), and "Tom Sawyer also, but not from an individual—he is a combination of the characteristics of three boys whom I knew."(no content)Twain said he based the character of Sawyer on himself and two childhood friends, John B. Briggs and William Bowen.

## Autobiographical Elements

Mark Twain describes some autobiographical events in the book. The novel's setting of St. Petersburg is based on Twain's actual boyhood home of Hannibal, near St. Louis, and many of the places in it are real and today support a tourist industry as a result.(no content)Decades later, his memories turned back to those years and he wrote the most popular boys' story of all time, The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876), setting it in a village like that of his own youth and giving Tom a home almost identical to his own.

## Other Character Inspirations

The search also revealed that other characters had real-life inspirations from Twain's Hannibal childhood:
- Thatcher was based on Twain's real-life childhood crush, Laura Hawkins. Like Twain, Hawkins had moved to Hannibal as a child, and her family lived on the same street as the Clemens family.
- Although Twain initially claimed to have invented the character entirely, he later admitted that Finn was based on Tom Blankenship. The son of the town drunkard, Blankenship was nonetheless idolized by the boys of Hannibal, who relished his sense of freedom and easy ways.

The search confirms that Tom Sawyer was deeply rooted in Mark Twain's childhood experiences in Hannibal, Missouri, drawing from his personal memories and real people from his youth.
